Timon S. Gutleb

PhD student in applied mathematics

Email: timon.gutleb@gmail.com

About Me

I am a PhD student of applied mathematics at Imperial College London, with a background in mathematics, physics and philosophy. I am also an associated student of the doctoral program “Dissipation and Dispersion in Nonlinear PDEs” through the University of Vienna.

My research focus is on numerical analysis and the development of computational tools for PDEs, integral equations and fractional differential equations with an eye on applications in the natural sciences such as relativistic quantum mechanics.

Projects

Numerics for equilibrium measures

Equilibrium measure problems appear, e.g. in the continuous mean-field limit of particle systems and thus have various applications ranging from the description of swarming and flocking behavior in animals and cells to self-assembly properties of particle systems.

Spectral methods for integral equations

Spectral methods are numerical methods which achieve exponential convergence through the use of appropriate approximation bases (such as orthogonal polynomials). When set up correctly, one obtains banded sparse linear systems which can be solved with high efficiency. I have worked towards using such methods to solve linear and nonlinear integral and integro-differential equations which have applications in the natural sciences and finance.

  • A fast sparse spectral method for nonlinear integro-differential Volterra equations with general kernels

    T. S. Gutleb , 2020.

  • A sparse spectral method for Volterra integral equations using orthogonal polynomials on the triangle

    T. S. Gutleb , S. Olver , 2019.

Splitting methods for relativistic Schrödinger-type equations

Relativistic variants of the Schrödinger equation such as the Pauli, Dirac and Klein-Gordon equations are used to model the behavior of particles moving at high velocities. When coupled to electromagnetic equations such as the Maxwell equations, these PDEs describing fermion and boson behavior are a challenge to solve numerically in the appropriate 3D context, even with benign assumptions on the potentials and boundaries. Lie and Strang splitting methods are a canonical approach to the numerical treatment of non-relativistic scalar Schrödinger equations - I have worked towards extending these methods to relativistic equations accounting for spin.

  • A time splitting method for the three-dimensional linear Pauli equation

    T. S. Gutleb , N. J. Mauser , M. Ruggeri , HP. Stimming , 2020.

Activities

Conference talks

  • ‘A sparse spectral method for Volterra integral equations using orthogonal polynomials on the triangle’, RMMM 2019, Vienna 2019.
  • ‘A sparse spectral method for Volterra integral equations’, 28th Biennial Numerical Analysis Conference, Glasgow 2019.
  • ‘BProbeM: a tool to measure matrix geometries’, Matrix Models for Noncommutative Geometry and String Theory, Vienna 2018.

Event Organizing

  • Organizer for the ‘Numerics of Schrödinger equations’ minisymposium at CMAM-9 (2020) with Hans-Peter Stimming.
  • Matthew Colbrook and I are organizing a joint PhD seminar series (CICS) between the University of Cambridge and Imperial College London centered around computational mathematics. Twice per term the seminar features PhD student talks from both departments as well as an invited plenary speaker.

Teaching

  • Student tutor for Analysis 1 and 2 for Physicists, first year undergraduate calculus courses (2015-2018), University of Vienna

Scientific Outreach and Volunteering

  • Volunteer work for paleoarxiv and the Phylogeny Explorer project (2018-2019)
  • Exhibition guide for the Austrian Academy of Sciences exhibit in celebration of 100 years of general relativity (2015)
  • Translator English → German for various educational platforms such as coursera.org and TED Talks (2015-2016)

Some open science projects I want to share

  • The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences (OEIS) is brilliant and incredibly useful for exploratory work in numerical analysis. I have tried to give back to it when and where possible (e.g. A334588) and hope you will consider doing so as well!
  • PrimeGrid is a BOINC-based volunteer distributed computing project which searches for prime numbers of various sizes and with various interesting properties. The largest AP-k my computers have found so far has been my AP-27 of length 21 in 2018 - perhaps your devices will be luckier?
  • I also share computing power with the BOINC-based distributed computing project Rosetta@home, which works towards designing new proteins and predicting their 3-dimensional shapes, with potential biomedical applications.
